bib.title: Will climate mitigation ambitions lead to carbon neutrality? An analysis of the local-level plans of 327 cities in the EU
bib.author: Monica Salvia and Diana Reckien and Filomena Pietrapertosa and Peter Eckersley and Niki-Artemis Spyridaki and Anna Krook-Riekkola and Marta Olazabal and Sonia De Gregorio Hurtado and Sofia G Simoes and Davide Geneletti and Vincent Viguié and Paris A Fokaides and Byron I Ioannou and Alexandros Flamos and Maria Szalmane Csete and Attila Buzasi and Hans Orru and Cheryl de Boer and Aoife Foley and Klavdija Rižnar and Marko Matosović and Mario V Balzan and Magdalena Smigaj and Viera Baštáková and Eva Streberova and Nataša Belšak Šel and Lana Coste and Léa Tardieu and Corinna Altenburg and Eliska Krkoška Lorencová and Kati Orru and Anja Wejs and Efren Feliu and Jon Marco Church and Stelios Grafakos and Sergiu Vasilie and Ivan Paspaldzhiev and Oliver Heidrich
bib.abstract: Cities across the globe recognise their role in climate mitigation and are acting to reduce carbon emissions. Knowing whether cities set ambitious climate and energy targets is critical for determining their contribution towards the global 1.5 °C target, partly because it helps to identify areas where further action is necessary. This paper presents a comparative analysis of the mitigation targets of 327 European cities, as declared in their local climate plans. The sample encompasses over 25% of the EU population and includes cities of all sizes across all Member States, plus the UK. The study analyses whether the type of plan, city size, membership of climate networks, and its regional location are associated with different levels of mitigation ambition.
